details.title: Using Extended R-Impact to Assess Journal Influence

p: Xiaoping Zhou is currently a Master Degree student in the Department of Mathematics at Beijing Institute Technology. His research interest is in the application of probability and statistics.

Guoxiao Yang is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics at Beijing Institute of Technology. He received his Ph.D in Pure Mathematics from Peking University in 1991. His research interests are in financial mathematics, and financial engineering.

details.abstract: <para> The objective of this study is to evaluate the importance or contributions of a journal to the development of disciplines. We introduce generalized impact factor, which involves the historical citation observed, and potential future citation of a journal. It can be used to assess the journal influence dynamically. Gamma distributions are used to fit the distribution of the citation frequency. Variations of impact factor are used to rank the relative influence of several journals in biology. </para>

references.title:
R-Impact: Reliability-based citation impact
factor

context.text: Reliability-based citation impact factor (RIF) is defined as the cited half-life multiplied by the citation impact factor [7], which can properly measure the effectiveness instead of just the short-term performance of journals.
To investigate the publication and citation of a journal in \$T\$ years, we use the publication-citation matrix which was given by Liang & Rousseau [7], shown in Table I.
The cited half-life \$H\$, which is defined as the number of publication years from the current year which account for 50% of current citations received [7], can be extended as \$H=F^{-1}(1/2)\$.

references.text: W. Kuo, R. Jason, "R-Impact: Reliability-based citation impact factor", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 56, no. 3, pp. 366-367, 2007.
